history.content: Many of our students choose to P/NP their HSS courses, and this does not seem to be a problem for employers or grad school. I think it would be much more of an issue to P/NP technical courses. If the rest of your grades are good, some P/NP grades in courses unrelated to your major are ok. (Some courses can only be taken P/NP, so some of these grades are inevitable.) If there is a trend of many, many P/NP grades, this may pose questions. This being said, it probably depends on the employer/grad school who is evaluating your record.

Many of our students choose to P/NP their HSS courses, and this does not seem to be a problem for employers or grad school. I think it would be much more of an issue to P/NP technical courses. If the rest of your grades are good, some P/NP grades in courses unrelated to your major are ok. (Some courses can only be taken P/NP, so some of these grades are inevitable.) If there is a trend of many, many P/NP grades, this may pose questions.

So I've basically been P/NPing all my breadth classes thus far. I've also been taking a lot of decals so I have quite a few P/NP units. I am just curious if this has any consequences. I know that we need to make sure to only take 1/3 our units P/NP but I was just wondering if P/NP units look bad to employers or grad school etc. Thank you.
history.subject: Do P/NP Units Look Bad?
